For he that cometh to God must believe that he is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently seek him. So we think about this subject matter of faith and unbelief. I preached a series actually several years ago on Sunday morning that I entitled Increase Our Faith, and we looked at a number of passages of Scripture throughout the Word of God that God could use in our lives as being faith builders. The disciples say to the Lord in Luke 17 in verse number 5, they say, Lord, increase our faith. And we studied for an entire year on Sunday mornings various passages of Scripture on how we could have our faith increased, and I often said this during that particular series, that if faith is a flower, then doubt or unbelief is a weed. And if we want the flower to grow, we got to deal with the weeds. Amen? I don't have a garden. We have some flower beds here at church. In fact, Dean and his mom were here this afternoon pulling weeds. And Mrs. Sparks mentioned to me that I wish the flowers at my house grew as well as the weeds at church grow. How many of you have seen it to be so that the weeds seem to grow very well? But if faith is a flower, then doubt or unbelief is a weed and needs to be dealt with. Because what do the weeds do? They choke out the flowers. Do they not? I read just last week about a Canadian thistle, and they mentioned that just the depth at which the root system of this thistle can go, not only the depth in which it can go, but how far out it can spread. And in just an acre of property, if there's simply five of those thistle plants, it can reduce the yield of that acre by nearly 25%. That's amazing. That's how weeds work. We need to learn how to recognize when I'm doubting, when I'm not trusting, when I'm not exercising faith, when I'm not living by faith. I'm not trusting God.
